title: Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence Syndrome
chief_complaint: I hear a pulsing sound in my ear, and I get dizzy when I hear loud noises or strain myself. I can hear my eyes move, and if I hum loudly, the room starts to spin.

problem_summary.onset: Not specified, but history implies chronic/ongoing symptoms.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Pulsatile tinnitus, noise-induced nystagmus (Tullio's), dizziness with straining (Valsalva), autophony (hearing eyes move, own voice loud), anxiety.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Severe dizziness handicap (DHI 64/100) and significant anxiety.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking diagnosis and relief from disorienting vestibular and auditory symptoms.

history.present_illness: Patient reports dizziness exposed to loud sound and during bowel movements. He can hear a 250-Hz tuning fork placed on his left ankle. He reports hearing his eyes move and experiencing vertigo when humming.
history.otologic_history: Previous CT scan reportedly showed SSC walls were thin but intact; however, symptoms strongly suggest SSCDS.
history.medical_psych_history: Significant for anxiety, pulmonary embolism, morbid obesity, and hypercoagulability disorder. Meds: Zoloft.
history.prior_management: Previous CT scan (read as thin but intact).

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Slight conductive loss. Left ear: Mild, mixed hearing loss (predominantly low/mid frequency). Supranormal bone conduction thresholds observed on the left (better than 0 dB HL), creating a significant air-bone gap.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition scores bilaterally despite threshold shifts.

tests.name: Tympanometry & Reflexes
tests.key_findings: Normal tympanograms (Type A). Acoustic reflexes are present at normal levels bilaterally. The presence of reflexes in the context of a conductive hearing loss (air-bone gap) is a hallmark sign of a third-window lesion (like SSCDS) rather than middle ear pathology.

tests.name: Self-Report Scales
tests.key_findings: Scores indicate severe perceived handicap from dizziness and significant anxiety levels.

tests.name: Videonystagmography (VNG) & Calorics
tests.key_findings: Standard ocular motility and positional tests were normal. Caloric testing was normal (no weakness). However, video recording captured downbeating nystagmus when the patient hummed, suggesting activation of the SSC crista.

tests.name: Video Head Impulse Test (vHIT)
tests.key_findings: Normal VOR gains in all planes (Lateral, RALP, LARP).

tests.name: Cervical VEMP (cVEMP)
tests.key_findings: 500 Hz thresholds were relatively symmetrical (atypical for SSCDS). However, a response was present at 4000 Hz in the Left (affected) ear, which is abnormal (high frequency VEMPs should not occur in healthy ears).

tests.name: Ocular VEMP (oVEMP)
tests.key_findings: Massive amplitude asymmetry. The Left (affected) ear produced a huge response compared to the right. A response was also recorded at 4000 Hz on the Left side only.

tests.name: CT Imaging
tests.key_findings: High-resolution coronal views confirm normal coverage on the right and dehiscence (missing bone) of the superior semicircular canal on the left.

overall_audiologic_summary: The evaluation reveals a classic presentation of Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence Syndrome (SSCDS) on the left side. Audiometrically, this manifests as a low-frequency conductive hearing loss with supranormal bone conduction thresholds and preserved acoustic reflexes. Vestibular testing confirms the diagnosis through a massive oVEMP amplitude asymmetry favoring the left ear, the presence of high-frequency (4000 Hz) VEMP responses on the left, and downbeating nystagmus provoked by humming.
counseling_points: Your symptoms are caused by a small thinning or opening in the bone over one of your balance canals (the superior canal). This creates a 'third window' in the inner ear.
This opening allows sound and pressure to leak into the balance system, which explains why loud noises or straining make you dizzy.
It also lets internal sounds (like your voice or eye movements) vibrate the ear more than usual, which is why you hear them so loudly (autophony).
The hearing loss on your left side is not due to a problem with the ear canal or middle ear bones, but rather this leak of energy in the inner ear.
Treatment options range from avoiding triggers (loud sounds) to surgical repair (plugging or resurfacing the canal) depending on how much this affects your quality of life.
notes_for_actor: Portray significant anxiety; you are worried about why you can 'hear your eyes move'.
If asked to hum loudly, describe or act out a sensation of the room spinning or moving vertically.
Emphasize that your own voice sounds incredibly loud and 'booming' in your left ear.
